summary: David H. Blee is identified as the author of two letters, both dated May 21, 1982, addressed to Anthony C. M. DeVere. These letters provide information on Valeriy Vladimirovich Kostikov, detailing his activities in Mexico City, his handling of Lee Harvey Oswald's visa request, and his suspected involvement with Central American communist parties. The documents suggest Blee was involved in intelligence gathering and reporting, specifically concerning individuals of interest in relation to the JFK assassination and Soviet intelligence operations. The letters highlight Kostikov's potential connection to Lee Harvey Oswald and his alleged ties to Department 13, indicating Blee's role in investigating and documenting these connections.
significance: David H. Blee's significance in the JFK context lies in his role in documenting and reporting on Valeriy Vladimirovich Kostikov's potential connections to Lee Harvey Oswald. His letters provide insights into the CIA's investigation of possible Soviet involvement in the JFK assassination, specifically focusing on Kostikov's alleged handling of Oswald's visa request and his broader intelligence activities. Blee's work contributes to the understanding of the CIA's efforts to assess and document potential links between Oswald and Soviet intelligence operatives.
